questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with dry, flaky skin, particularly on her hands and feet. On examination, her skin appears rough and has a tendency to peel. You suspect a genetic mutation affecting a specific protein critical for skin barrier function. Which layer of the epidermis is primarily responsible for producing this protein, and what is its function?

options.label: A
options.text: Stratum spinosum, regulating melanin production and skin pigmentation.

options.label: B
options.text: Stratum lucidum, enhancing skin elasticity and collagen synthesis.

options.label: C
options.text: Stratum basale, promoting cell proliferation and wound healing.

options.label: D
options.text: Stratum granulosum, facilitating keratinocyte maturation and formation of the skin barrier.

questions.correct_answer: D. Stratum granulosum, facilitating keratinocyte maturation and formation of the skin barrier.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stratum granulosum, facilitating keratinocyte maturation and formation of the skin barrier.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Filaggrin is a vital protein produced in the stratum granulosum, the third layer of the epidermis. It plays a crucial role in the process of keratinization, where keratinocytes undergo transformation into corneocytes. Filaggrin binds to keratin intermediate filaments, aggregating them and promoting the formation of a strong, structured protein network within corneocytes. This process is essential for the integrity and cohesion of the stratum granulosum, which serves as the skin's protective barrier against external stressors, pathogens, and water loss.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stratum spinosum, regulating melanin production and skin pigmentation: The stratum spinosum is the layer of the epidermis located above the stratum basale. It contains keratinocytes that are connected by desmosomes, giving it a spiny appearance. This layer is involved in the synthesis of keratin but not in the primary production of filaggrin, nor does it regulate melanin production and skin pigmentation.
  • • Option A. Stratum spinosum, regulating melanin production and skin pigmentation:
  • • Option B. Stratum lucidum, enhancing skin elasticity and collagen synthesis: The stratum lucidum is a thin, clear layer found only in the thick skin of the palms and soles. It provides an extra barrier against friction but is not involved in filaggrin production or enhancing skin elasticity and collagen synthesis.
  • • Option B. Stratum lucidum, enhancing skin elasticity and collagen synthesis:
  • • Option C. Stratum basale, promoting cell proliferation and wound healing: The stratum basale is the deepest layer of the epidermis, where active cell division (proliferation) occurs. While this layer is essential for continuously producing new keratinocytes to replenish the upper layers of the epidermis, filaggrin is not primarily involved in cell proliferation or wound healing processes.
  • • Option C. Stratum basale, promoting cell proliferation and wound healing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stratum granulosum of the epidermis is responsible for keratinocyte maturation and the production of essential proteins, like filaggrin, that contribute to the formation of the skin barrier. Mutations affecting these proteins can lead to conditions characterized by dry, flaky skin, such as ichthyosis vulgaris and atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with blisters on her hands and feet after minor trauma. On examination, you notice that the blisters are located at the level where the epidermis meets the dermis. You suspect a condition affecting the structural integrity of the dermo-epidermal junction. Which of the following statements about the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The DEJ is primarily formed by Type IV collagen.

options.label: B
options.text: The part of the dermis that invaginates into the epidermis is called Rete Ridges.

options.label: C
options.text: The DEJ is solely responsible for providing adhesion between the epidermis and dermis.

options.label: D
options.text: The DEJ is also known as the Dermal Papilla.

questions.correct_answer: A. The DEJ is primarily formed by Type IV collagen.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The DEJ is primarily formed by Type IV collagen.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The dermo-epidermal junction is predominantly formed by Type IV collagen. Type IV collagen is a structural protein that contributes to the integrity and stability of the DEJ. It forms a network that provides support and attachment between the epidermis and dermis, playing a crucial role in skin resilience.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. The part of the dermis that invaginates into the epidermis is called Rete Ridges: Rete ridges are actually the part of the epidermis that invaginates into the dermis, forming ridges and valleys on the skin's surface. They are crucial for increasing the surface area for better attachment and nutrient exchange between the epidermis and dermis.
  • • Option B. The part of the dermis that invaginates into the epidermis is called Rete Ridges:
  • • Option C. The DEJ is solely responsible for providing adhesion between the epidermis and dermis: While the DEJ plays a significant role in adhesion between the epidermis and dermis, it is not solely responsible. Hemidesmosomes and anchoring fibrils also contribute to the attachment and overall structural integrity between these layers.
  • • Option C. The DEJ is solely responsible for providing adhesion between the epidermis and dermis:
  • • Option D. The DEJ is also known as the Dermal Papilla: The dermal papilla refers to the part of the dermis that invaginates into the epidermis, particularly in hair follicles. It is not synonymous with the DEJ, which is the interface between the dermis and epidermis throughout the skin.
  • • Option D. The DEJ is also known as the Dermal Papilla:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ) is primarily formed by Type IV collagen, providing structural integrity and stability between the epidermis and dermis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by her parents, who are concerned about unusual skin lesions that have developed over the past few weeks. The lesions initially appeared as blisters and have since evolved into streaky and whorled hyperpigmented lines, predominantly along the trunk and limbs, as shown in the image. The parents mention that several female relatives on the mother's side have had similar skin findings. Which of the following best describes the distribution pattern of these lesions?
questions.correct_answer: B. Along lines of embryonic development
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Along lines of embryonic development

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The described skin lesions and their evolution from vesicular to hyperpigmented lines, along with the familial pattern observed in female relatives, are characteristic of Incontinentia pigmenti. This rare genetic condition is linked to the IKBKG gene and is X-linked dominant, typically affecting females. The lesions follow the lines of Blaschko, which represent the paths of embryonic cell migration. These lines do not correspond to other anatomical structures like blood vessels, nerves, or lymphatics but rather indicate developmental patterns established during embryogenesis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Along nerves: Lesions following nerves would typically present in a dermatomal distribution, as seen in conditions like herpes zoster. The distribution pattern in the presented case does not fit this description.
  • • Option A. Along nerves:
  • • Option C. Along blood vessels: Lesions along blood vessels would manifest differently, often presenting as vascular malformations or related conditions. The linear and whorled pattern seen here does not align with vascular distributions.
  • • Option C. Along blood vessels:
  • • Option D. Along lymphatics: Lymphatic involvement usually presents with swelling or edema and would not result in the streaky, hyperpigmented lines described. This distribution is inconsistent with the pathogenesis of incontinentia pigmenti.
  • • Option D. Along lymphatics:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incontinentia pigmenti lesions follow the lines of Blaschko, which represent the embryonic developmental pathways.

options.label: A
options.text: Synthesis of keratin mainly occurs in Stratum spinosum

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Keratinocytes are principal cells of dermis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Keratinocytes are the principal cells of the epidermis, not the dermis. The dermis is primarily composed of fibroblasts, which produce collagen and elastin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Synthesis of keratin: Synthesis of keratin does mainly occur in the stratum spinosum, also known as the "prickle cell layer," which is responsible for the majority of keratin production in the epidermis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Synthesis of keratin:
  • • Option B. Odland bodies: Odland bodies, also known as lamellar granules, are indeed found in the stratum granulosum. They contain lipids and enzymes, which are secreted into the intercellular spaces to form a water-repellent barrier.
  • • Option B.
  • • Odland bodies:
  • • Option D. Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are antigen-presenting cells and are indeed located in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis.
  • • Option D. Langerhans cells:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The keratinocytes are the primary cells of the epidermis , where they synthesize keratin. The dermis, on the other hand, contains fibroblasts as the main cells responsible for producing collagen and other components of connective tissue.
  • ➤ keratinocytes
  • ➤ epidermis
  • ➤ fibroblasts

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Merkel cells & Melanocytes are present in Stratum Basale

options.label: B
options.text: Separation of keratinocytes is called as Acantholysis

options.label: C
options.text: Thickening of Stratum spinosum is called as Acanthosis

options.label: D
options.text: Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The skin turnover time in psoriasis is accelerated and is typically around 3-5 days, not 8 weeks. The normal turnover time for skin is approximately 42-75 days. The rapid turnover rate in psoriasis leads to the characteristic plaques seen in the disorder.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Merkel cells & Melanocytes: Both Merkel cells, which are tactile cells, and melanocytes, which produce the pigment melanin, are indeed located in the stratum basale (basal layer) of the epidermis.
  • • Option A. Merkel cells & Melanocytes:
  • • Option B. Acantholysis: Acantholysis refers to the loss of intercellular connections resulting in the separation of keratinocytes, which is seen in conditions such as Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • • Option B. Acantholysis:
  • • Option C. Acanthosis : Acanthosis is the thickening of the stratum spinosum and is a characteristic finding in conditions such as chronic eczema and psoriasis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Acanthosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In psoriasis, the epidermal turnover time is drastically shortened to 3-7 days, leading to rapid skin cell proliferation and scaling. The normal skin turnover cycle is around 4 weeks, but psoriasis accelerates this process significantly.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with a 2-week history of progressive blistering involving her oral mucosa and trunk. On examination, multiple flaccid blisters with erythematous bases are noted, and the blisters easily rupture with gentle pressure. A skin biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence staining shows intercellular deposition of IgG within the epidermis. Which of the following is most likely targeted by the immune system in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Desmosomes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the production of autoantibodies against components of the desmosomes, particularly desmogleins which are cadherin-type proteins critical for cell-cell adhesion in the epidermis. The loss of adhesion between keratinocytes, known as acantholysis, leads to the formation of flaccid blisters. The direct immunofluorescence staining pattern shown, with intercellular IgG deposits, is typical for pemphigus vulgaris, confirming that the immune system targets desmosomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Keratinocytes: While keratinocytes are affected in pemphigus vulgaris, they are not the direct target of the immune response; rather, the antibodies target the desmosomes which are adhesive structures within the keratinocytes.
  • • Option A. Keratinocytes:
  • • Option B. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are the cells responsible for pigment production in the skin, and they are not targeted in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • • Option B. Melanocytes:
  • • Option C. Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are antigen-presenting cells in the skin, and they are not the target in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • • Option C. Langerhans cells:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immune system targets desmosomes in pemphigus vulgaris, leading to a loss of keratinocyte adhesion and the formation of intraepidermal blisters.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of progressive hair thinning and hair loss, which is diagnosed as androgenic alopecia. The physician discusses various treatment options and medications with the patient. Which of the following is contraindicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Testosterone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Androgenic alopecia, also known as male pattern baldness, is influenced by androgens, particularly dihydrotestosterone (DHT). Treatments for androgenic alopecia aim to either block the effects of androgens or stimulate hair growth.
  • • Testosterone or other androgenic hormones are contraindicated in androgenic alopecia as they can exacerbate the condition by increasing DHT levels, which contribute to hair follicle miniaturization and hair loss.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cyproterone Acetate: Cyproterone acetate is an anti-androgen that blocks androgen receptors and reduces androgen production. It is sometimes used in women with androgenic alopecia but is not commonly used in men due to its anti-androgenic effects.
  • • Option B. Cyproterone Acetate:
  • • Option C. Finasteride: Finasteride is an oral medication that inhibits the enzyme 5-alpha-reductase, which converts testosterone to DHT. It is FDA-approved for the treatment of androgenic alopecia in men.
  • • Option C. Finasteride:
  • • Option D. Minoxidil: Minoxidil is a topical treatment that stimulates hair growth and is commonly used to treat androgenic alopecia. It is available over the-counter and is applied directly to the scalp.
  • • Option D. Minoxidil:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testosterone is contraindicated in the treatment of androgenic alopecia as it can worsen hair loss by increasing DHT levels. Treatments such as cyproterone acetate (in women), finasteride, and minoxidil are used to manage androgenic alopecia by either blocking androgens or promoting hair growth.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a patch of hair loss on the left temporal region. Upon examination, the scalp appears normal with no signs of inflammation, scaling, or other visible abnormalities. The patient reports that the hair loss occurred suddenly. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alopecia areata

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition characterized by sudden, well-demarcated patches of hair loss. The underlying skin appears normal without any signs of inflammation, scaling, or scarring, distinguishing it from other causes of hair loss. The presence of a single patch of hair loss in a young adult, with a normal-appearing scalp, strongly suggests this diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Telogen effluvium: Telogen effluvium typically presents with diffuse hair thinning rather than a localized patch of hair loss. It is caused by a disruption in the hair growth cycle, often triggered by stress, illness, or hormonal changes.
  • • Option A. Telogen effluvium:
  • • Option C. Male-pattern baldness: Male-pattern baldness, or androgenetic alopecia, presents with a gradual thinning of hair primarily in the frontal, temporal, and vertex regions. It does not cause sudden, well-defined patches of hair loss with a normal scalp.
  • • Option C. Male-pattern baldness:
  • • Option D. Tinea capitis: Tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp, usually presents with patchy hair loss accompanied by inflammation, scaling, and sometimes pustules or black dots where hair has broken off. The absence of these signs makes this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option D. Tinea capitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alopecia areata presents as sudden, well-demarcated patches of hair loss with a normal-appearing scalp, distinguishing it from other causes of hair loss.

questions.text: A patient presents with lesion on occipital region of head as shown in the image below. On examination boggy swelling was noted over scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tinea capitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that typically presents with patchy hair loss, scaling, and sometimes with a boggy swelling known as a kerion, which is an inflammatory mass that can be tender and may exude pus. The boggy swelling mentioned in the examination findings is highly indicative of a kerion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option. A Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes, presenting with purple, pruritic, polygonal papules, and is not typically associated with boggy swellings or pus.
  • • Option. A Lichen planus
  • • Option C Traumatic alopecia refers to hair loss due to physical damage to the hair shaft or follicle from practices such as tight braiding or chemical burns. It does not present with boggy swelling or the inflammation as seen in the image.
  • • Option C Traumatic alopecia
  • • Option D Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic form of eczema that affects areas of the body with a high density of sebaceous glands, including the scalp, but it typically presents with flaky, white to yellowish scales on oily areas such as the scalp and is not associated with a boggy swelling.
  • • Option D Seborrheic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea capitis is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with a lesion on the occipital region of the head accompanied by a boggy swelling, indicative of a kerion, a classic presentation of a fungal scalp infection.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The oil drop sign is a nail finding typically seen in psoriasis, not lichen planus. It presents as a translucent, yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

  • ➤ nail psoriasis

questions.text: A 24-year-old married woman presents with multiple nodular, cystic, pustular, and comedone lesions on her face, upper back, and shoulders that have been present for the past two years. Before initiating treatment, what is the best advice for her?

options.label: B
options.text: Start OCP and avoid pregnancy during treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Have a course of antibiotics for 15 days

options.label: D
options.text: Have a course of anti-inflammatory for 15 days

questions.correct_answer: B. Start OCP and avoid pregnancy during treatment
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start OCP and avoid pregnancy during treatment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with severe acne, characterized by nodular and cystic lesions, which may require treatment with medications that are teratogenic, such as isotretinoin. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are recommended to prevent pregnancy during treatment due to the high risk of birth defects associated with isotretinoin and other retinoids. Additionally, OCPs can also help in controlling acne by regulating hormones that contribute to acne formation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Get pregnant, then start treatment : This option is inappropriate because many effective acne treatments, especially for severe cases, are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenicity.
  • • Option A. Get pregnant, then start treatment
  • • Option C. Have a course of antibiotics for 15 days : Antibiotics may be part of the treatment regimen for acne, particularly for inflammatory acne. However, a short 15-day course is typically insufficient for the treatment of severe acne, and long-term management strategies are necessary.
  • • Option C. Have a course of antibiotics for 15 days
  • • Option D. Have a course of anti-inflammatory for 15 days : Anti-inflammatory medications alone are not a standard treatment for acne. Acne requires a multi-faceted approach, including topical or systemic antibiotics, retinoids, and hormonal therapies, particularly for severe cases.
  • • Option D. Have a course of anti-inflammatory for 15 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women of childbearing age with severe acne, it is crucial to use effective contraception, such as oral contraceptive pills, to prevent pregnancy during treatment due to the teratogenic potential of many acne medications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a known history of psoriasis presents to the dermatology clinic for a routine follow-up. During the visit, she asks about the various sites of involvement in psoriasis and which areas are LEAST likely to be affected. Which of the following is the LEAST common site of involvement in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CNS involvement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that can affect multiple areas of the body. Common sites of involvement include:
  • • Central nervous system (CNS) involvement is not a feature of psoriasis. Psoriasis is primarily a skin and joint disease, and it does not affect the CNS. Therefore, CNS involvement is the least common site of involvement in psoriasis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scalp: Scalp involvement is very common in psoriasis and can present with thick, scaly plaques.
  • • Option A. Scalp:
  • • Option B. Nail involvement: Nail psoriasis is also common, with features such as pitting, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis.
  • • Option B. Nail involvement:
  • • Option D. Arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is a well-recognized comorbidity of psoriasis, affecting the joints and causing symptoms such as pain, swelling, and stiffness.
  • • Option D. Arthritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The least common site of involvement in psoriasis is the central nervous system (CNS), as psoriasis primarily affects the skin, nails, and joints.

questions.text: Arrange the following structures in the skin in the order from most superficial to deepest: Desmoglein Hemidesmosomes Collagen VII Laminin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To understand the arrangement of these structures from most superficial to deepest in the skin, it's important to consider their anatomical locations and functions:
  • • 1. Desmoglein: This protein is part of desmosomes, which are found in the epidermis, specifically in the keratinocytes of the stratum spinosum, making it the most superficial in this list.
  • • 1. Desmoglein:
  • • 2. Hemidesmosomes : These structures are found at the basal surface of keratinocytes in the epidermis, anchoring them to the basement membrane.
  • • 2. Hemidesmosomes
  • • 4. Laminin: This is a component of the basement membrane itself, lying just beneath the hemidesmosomes and connecting them to the underlying dermis.
  • • 4. Laminin:
  • • 3. Collagen VII: This type of collagen is found in the anchoring fibrils below the basement membrane, securing the dermo-epidermal junction, making it the deepest structure in this list.
  • • 3. Collagen VII:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the skin, desmoglein is found in the upper epidermis, hemidesmosomes anchor the basal cells to the basement membrane, laminin is a key component of the basement membrane, and collagen VII forms anchoring fibrils below the basement membrane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with flaccid bullae and erosions over the oral mucous membrane. The blisters developed into painful erosions upon rupturing. What would be the most likely finding on an immunofluorescent examination of the skin biopsy of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Linear IgA deposition in dermoepidermal junction

options.label: B
options.text: Linear IgG deposition in dermoepidermal junction

options.label: D
options.text: Granular deposits of IgA in dermal papillae

questions.correct_answer: C. Fishnet IgG deposition in epidermis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fishnet IgG deposition in epidermis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of flaccid bullae and erosions, especially involving the oral mucous membrane, is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris. This autoimmune blistering disorder is caused by autoantibodies against desmoglein, a component of desmosomes in the epidermis. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of a skin biopsy in pemphigus vulgaris shows intercellular deposition of IgG and C3 in a “fishnet” or “chicken-wire” pattern within the epidermis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Linear IgA deposition in dermoepidermal junction: This pattern is typically seen in linear IgA bullous dermatosis, a different blistering disorder characterized by linear deposits of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction.
  • • Option A. Linear IgA deposition in dermoepidermal junction:
  • • Option B. Linear IgG deposition in dermoepidermal junction: This pattern is seen in bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease characterized by subepidermal blisters with linear IgG and C3 deposition at the basement membrane zone.
  • • Option B. Linear IgG deposition in dermoepidermal junction:
  • • Option D. Granular deposits of IgA in dermal papillae: This finding is indicative of dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease, where granular IgA deposits are found in the dermal papillae.
  • • Option D. Granular deposits of IgA in dermal papillae:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by flaccid bullae and erosions, especially on mucous membranes. Immunofluorescent examination typically shows fishnet-like deposition of IgG in the epidermis.

questions.text: Arrange the following blistering disorders from superficial to deep: Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid Pemphigus foliaceous EB Dystrophica
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3, 1, 2, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To arrange blistering disorders from superficial to deep, it is important to understand where the blisters form in relation to the skin layers:
  • • 3. Pemphigus foliaceous: This disorder affects the most superficial layer of the epidermis, specifically the granular layer, leading to superficial blistering.
  • • 3. Pemphigus foliaceous:
  • • 1. Pemphigus vulgaris: This disorder affects the deeper layers within the epidermis, specifically the suprabasal layer, resulting in intraepidermal blisters.
  • • 1. Pemphigus vulgaris:
  • • 2. Bullous pemphigoid: This disorder involves the subepidermal space, with blisters forming just below the epidermis but above the basement membrane.
  • • 2. Bullous pemphigoid:
  • • 4. EB Dystrophica (Epidermolysis Bullosa Dystrophica): This disorder involves the deepest layer, where the blisters form below the basement membrane in the dermis due to defects in collagen VII.
  • • 4. EB Dystrophica (Epidermolysis Bullosa Dystrophica):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus foliaceous, pemphigus vulgaris, bullous pemphigoid, and EB Dystrophica form blisters at progressively deeper levels within the skin, from the superficial granular layer to the deep dermal layer.

questions.text: Match the ectopic sebaceous glands listed with their corresponding site: Choose the correct match from the options below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-e

questions.explanation:

It is characterized by a deficiency or functional impairment of profilaggrin, a protein found in the stratum granulosum layer of the epidermis. Profilaggrin is a key component in the formation of filaggrin, which plays a critical role in skin hydration and barrier function.
